security: Revealing operational details, agent identities (C-1, C-4, Miami case officer), and communication methods (SW system, couriers) could compromise intelligence operations and endanger individuals. Specifically, the memo mentions 'only the DCI has the authority to release such information,' indicating the sensitivity of agent identities. Sharing CIA's assessment of United Revolucionaria could also reveal intelligence on the organization's activities and undermine relationships. Providing names and information on agents and assets could expose them to harm from hostile entities.
summary: A memorandum detailing a briefing between CIA and MI-6 regarding Robert Morten Geddes, a British subject suspected of being a provocateur in Cuba. The meeting aimed to provide MI-6 with information on Geddes' contacts with the CIA and his activities related to a supposed Cuban Navy defection, while also addressing MI-6's concerns about potential Cuban manipulation of the situation.
summary_one_paragraph: On May 4, 1961, a secret memorandum documented a briefing between Mr. Maurice Oldfield of MI-6 and Clark Simmons of the CIA, along with others, concerning Robert Morten Geddes, a British subject believed to be a provocateur in Cuba. Oldfield sought details about Geddes' CIA contacts, methods of communication, and the agency's assessment of the United Revolucionaria, as he feared the Cubans might exploit Geddes to provoke the British Embassy. Simmons shared a chronology of Geddesâ€™ activities, noting his reports about a potential Cuban Navy defection were suspect from the beginning, but he withheld specific agent identities, stating only the DCI had the authority to release them. The meeting concluded with Oldfield planning to inform MI-6 that Geddes might be a 'glossy'.
title: Briefing of Mr. Maurice Oldfield, MI-6, by WR/4, Clark Simmons
